{{Infobox musical artist | name = Junior Parker | image = Junior Parker.jpg | caption = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Herman Parker, Jr. | alias = Mr Blues, Little Junior Parker | birth_date = {{birth date|1932|5|27}} | birth_place = [[Clarksdale, Mississippi]] or [[West Memphis, Arkansas]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1971|11|18|1932|5|27}} | death_place = [[Blue Island, Illinois]] | instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]], [[harmonica]] | genre = [[Blues]], [[Electric blues]], [[Gospel music|Gospel]], [[Memphis blues]], [[Rock and roll]], [[Rockabilly]]{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p112422|pure_url=no|label=Junior Parker}} | occupation = [[Musician]] | years_active = 1951–1971 | label = [[Sun Records]]
[[Modern Records]]
[[Capitol Records|Capitol]] | associated_acts = The Blue Flames, [[Pat Hare]], [[Ike Turner]] | website = }} '''Junior Parker''' (May 27, 1932 – November 18, 1971) was an [[United States|American]] [[Memphis blues]] [[singing|singer]] and [[musician]].''Junior Parker was born on May 27, in 1932. He was an African-American Blues singer and musician'' [http://www.aaregistry.com/african_american_history/1424/Junior_Parker_Mr_Blues] retrieved 08/15/07 He is best remembered for his unique voice, which has been described as "honeyed," and "velvet-smooth".''Parker's voice described.'' http://www.pbs.org/theblues/roadtrip/mem-louissongs.html retrieved 08/26/07 He was posthumously inducted into the [[Blues Hall of Fame]] in 2001.''In 2001, Parker was inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame.'' [http://www.aaregistry.com/african_american_history/1424/Junior_Parker_Mr_Blues] retrieved 08/15/07 One [[music journalism|music journalist]] noted, "For years Junior Parker deserted downhome harmonica blues for uptown blues-soul music".{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= [[Carlton Publishing Group|Carlton Books Limited]] | location= [[Dubai]] | page= 202 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} ==Biography== Junior Parker was born in either [[Clarksdale, Mississippi]],''Born in Clarksdale, Mississippi'' [http://www.aaregistry.com/african_american_history/1424/Junior_Parker_Mr_Blues] retrieved 08/15/07 or [[West Memphis, Arkansas]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=10118|title=Junior Parker:All About Jazz|accessdate=2010-10-11}} He sang in gospel groups as a child,[http://www.centrohd.com/biogra/p1/little_junior_parker_b.htm Little Junior Parker b] and played on the various blues circuits beginning in his teenage years. His biggest influence as a [[harmonica]] player was [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]],''harp style was personally mentored by none other than regional icon Sonny Boy Williamson.'' [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Junior_Parker&action=submit] retrieved 08/15/07 with whom he worked before moving on to work for [[Howlin' Wolf]] in 1949. Around 1950 he was a member of Memphis's ad hoc group, the Beale Streeters, with [[Bobby 'Blue' Bland]] and [[B.B. King]]. {{Listen | filename = Little Junior's Blue Flames - Love My Baby.ogg | title = Little Junior's Blue Flames - "Love My Baby" (1953) | description = "Love My Baby" (1953) by Little Junior's Blue Flames, featuring [[Pat Hare]] on the [[electric guitar]], is considered an important contribution to the [[rockabilly]] genre. | pos = left }} In 1951 he formed his own band, the Blue Flames, with the guitarist [[Pat Hare]].''Beale Streeters'' http://www.pbs.org/theblues/roadtrip/mem-louissongs.html Retrieved 08/26/07 Parker was discovered in 1952 by [[Ike Turner]], who signed him to [[Modern Records]]. He put out one single on this [[record label]], "You're My Angel."''first recording opportunity from talent scout Ike Turner'' [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Junior_Parker&action=submit] retrieved 08/15/07 This brought him to the attention of [[Sam Phillips]], and he and his band signed onto [[Sun Records]] in 1953. There they produced three successful songs: "Feelin' Good" (which reached # 5 on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]]), "Love My Baby," and "[[Mystery Train]]", later [[Cover version|covered]] by [[Elvis Presley]].''Parker wrote and recorded "Mystery Train" later covered by Elvis Presley.'' http://www.pbs.org/theblues/roadtrip/mem-louissongs.html retrieved 08/26/07 For Presley's version of "Mystery Train", [[Scotty Moore]] borrowed the guitar riff from Parker's "Love My Baby",[http://www.musicweb-international.com/encyclopaedia/p/P20.HTM PARKER, Little Junior : MusicWeb Encyclopaedia of Popular Music] played by Pat Hare.{{cite book|last=Gillett|first=Charlie|title=The sound of the city: the rise of rock and roll|year=1984|publisher=[[Pantheon Books]]|location=New York|isbn=0394726383|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=lkwUAQAAIAAJ|edition=Rev.|accessdate=6 July 2012|quote='Love My Baby' in particular featured some blistering guitar playing by Pat Hare, which inspired the rockabilly style discussed elsewhere.}} "Love My Baby" and "Mystery Train" are considered important contributions to the [[rockabilly]] genre.{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p112422|pure_url=no|label=Junior Parker}} Later in 1953, Parker toured with Bobby Bland and [[Johnny Ace]], and also joined [[Duke Records]]. Parker and Bland headed the highly successful Blues Consolidated Revue, which became a staple part of the southern blues circuit. He continued to have a string of hits on the R&B chart, including the smooth "[[Next Time You See Me]]" (1957); re-makes of [[Roosevelt Sykes|Roosevelt Sykes']] song "[[Driving Wheel (song)|Driving Wheel]]" (1961), Robert Johnson's "[[Sweet Home Chicago]]", [[Guitar Slim]]'s "[[The Things That I Used to Do]]" (1963), and [[Don Robey|Don Robey's]] "Mother-in-Law Blues" (1956); plus his own "Stand by Me" (1961). His success was limited after he left Duke in 1966. He recorded for various labels, including [[Mercury Records|Mercury]], Blue Rock, [[Minit Records|Minit]], and [[Capitol Records|Capitol]]. Parker died on November 18, 1971, at age 39, in [[Blue Island, Illinois]], during surgery for a [[brain tumor]]. ==Tributes== On his 1974 album ''[[Al Green Explores Your Mind|...Explores Your Mind]]'', [[Al Green]] dedicated his original version of the song "Take Me To The River" to Parker, who he describes as "a cousin of mine who's gone on, and we'd kinda like to carry on in his name."
